name: Advocacy Training for Community Health Workers
description: A free digital training that equips CHWs with the skills to effectively share their personal stories and promote the health issues most important to their communities.

repositories.name: main
repositories.url: N/A (training videos are shared via a CC BY-NC-SA 4.0 license)

sdg: SDG8: Decent Work and Economic Growth
sdgs.relevance:
SDG3: Good Health and Well-Being: CHWs are some of the most accessible and trusted frontline care providers in the world, especially in traditionally medically-underserved communities. By supporting these impactful workers, we support progress toward the Good Health and Well-Being targets by extending access to basic public health and primary care in vulnerable communities.


SDG8: Decent Work and Economic Growth: Many CHWs are unpaid and do not receive adequate support and training. Our advocacy training equips CHWs with the skills to push for inclusion in decision-making conversations to advocate for their rights.

clearOwnership.clearOwnershipName: Community Health Impact Coalition and Digital Medic, an initiative of the Stanford Center for Health Education

documentation:
https://digitalmedic.stanford.edu/our-work/free-advocacy-training/; https://digitalmedic.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/CHW-Advocacy-Course_-DM-App-Install-and-Set-up-Guide-for-iOS-and-Android.pdf; https://www.chwadvocates.app/; https://digitalmedic.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/v1_STUDENT_CHW-Advocacy-Storytelling.pdf; https://digitalmedic.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/v2_CHW-Advocacy-Storytelling-Training-Facilitator-Guide.pdf

The training is available via the Digital Medic mobile app and the progressive web application through CHIC: https://www.chwadvocates.app/. Content is the same, and so is the target audience of CHWs and CHW supervisors. There is also a documented student workbook as well as a facilitator guide to promote in-person and hybrid implementations.

NonPII.nonPIIAccessMechanism: We only collect data when learners take the course on the Digital Medic mobile app or through the CHIC web course, and this is only accessible to Digital Medic and CHIC.

openStandards: Standard content formats: PDF; Multimedia: MP4
bestPractices:
Principles for Digital Development: 
• Design with users: Created with a group of global CHW advisors
• Understand the existing ecosystem: CHW advisors and advocates involved in design and development

with a strong knowledge of communities and working conditions
• Design for scale: Created in an animated style for quick adaptation and translation to reach more communities
• Build for sustainability: Digital training that can be updated if needed
• Be data driven: Anonymous user data and surveys collected to inform distribution and effectiveness of training
• Use open standards

etc.: Creative Commons Share Alike license ensures free access to training
• Reuse and improve: Includes existing advocacy best practices and global goals

presented in a novel and engaging format
• Address privacy and security: All learner data is secure and anonymous
• Be collaborative: Designed as a collaborative training with the Community Health Impact Coalition
and a group of global CHW advisors
collaboration has been engrained in this training since its inception and throughout its development and distribution
